title: 115_hr3105
content: The Act may be cited as the "Supporting Grandparents Raising Grandchildren Act." Congress finds that over 80% of Americans over 65 are grandparents, with over 2.5 million serving as primary caretakers for their grandchildren. This number is increasing due to the opioid epidemic. While grandparents report benefits from caring for their grandchildren, it can also lead to physical and mental health issues and impact their ability to save for retirement. Additionally, they may face challenges in enrolling their grandchildren in school and accessing medical care. The Older Americans Act of 1965 includes services to support grandfamilies, such as the National Family Caregiver Support Program. Grandparents need better coordination and information on available resources for caregiving. Federal Task Force to Support Grandparents Raising Grandchildren. Establishment of a Federal Task Force To Support Grandparents Raising Grandchildren, composed of various government officials. The Task Force, led by the Department of Health and Human Services, consists of federal government officers or employees. Its duties include identifying and disseminating information on resources and best practices for grandparents or other relatives raising children. The Task Force, under the Department of Health and Human Services, aims to support grandparents or relatives raising children by addressing their health, educational, and emotional needs, especially those affected by the opioid epidemic. They also ensure Native American tribes' needs are met. Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, a report will be submitted to the Special Committee on Aging. The Task Force under the Department of Health and Human Services will submit a report to the Senate Committees on Aging and Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions, including best practices and identifying gaps in support for grandparents and relatives raising children. A follow-up report will be submitted two years later. The Task Force under the Department of Health and Human Services will establish a process for public input to inform the development of best practices and resources for grandparents and relatives raising children. The Task Force will terminate five years after the enactment of this Act.
